Shitposting aside and warriortard vs anti-warriortard disregarded. The warrior is a really bad IFV. ITT I will list it’s flaws. Note that these flaws are real, and the fact that there is a warriortard running around does not negate these flaws. These flaws make the warrior the single worst Cold War era IFV. Now, let’s begin
>non stabilized main gun
The thing can’t shoot unless it’s completely still
>no ATGM
At a time where the Bradley was earning a reputation popping enemy armor the warrior was sidelined
>fires from a 3 round clip
Only 12 rounds ready at any time
>no dual feed
The gunner couldn’t switch between ammo types with the press of a button. He had to either fire out the remaining 12 rounds and manually reload, or manually unload and reload to the desired ammo.

It’s one saving grace that it was well protected. It’s many massive flaws far outweigh its singular virtue. I’m sorry bongfags I just can’t stay silent anymore.

>>56072441
>I'm buying NFA items this week, will I wait until 2024 to get them
Hard to say, it could literally be 2024 but probably not. Current wait time is reaching 8 months but that's for things purchased 8 months ago. For the last five weeks the wait time has increased over 4 days each week. In other words the ATF isn't keeping up with the existing backlog and new filings received. If that trend continues then it could take over a year for something purchased today. Realistically that puts you back into paper form wait times that were 12-14 months recently. The one thing you can know is that the sooner you file your paperwork the sooner you'll receive it. Beyond that it's out of your control. Also, once you have one filed you can buy more while it's processing and the ATF will likely batch the requests together and approve them all at once. So your place in line is there and all your additional purchases will most likely get approved with the first one.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56070223
>It always seemed unfair to have one term for both 5.56 and 7.62x39 as they are very different.
Compared to pistol and full size rifle cartridges, they are not very different. On a scale of 9mm to .308 Winchester (say 1-10), for example. As far as those intermediates go, yes, they are very different.

>>56072463
>5.56, 5.45 and 5.8 chinesium are basically scaled down versions of full sized cartridges
Oh really now? Care to tell me which full sized rifle cartridge 5.56 was scaled down from? Same goes for 5.45 and 5.8, but I'd love to hear you explain how a cartridge that comes from .222 Remington, is in reality some sort of scaled .30 cal rifle cartridge.
>7.62x39, .300 blackout and 8mm kurz are the same caliber as full sized cartridges but shortened and lower powered
Absolute brainlet tier. 7.62x39 is not a shorted 7.62x54R, it differs in every single dimension save the diameter of the bullet. .300 Blackout? That's a .30 caliber bullet stuck in a .221 Fireball case, not a .308 Winchester shortened and lower powered. 8mm Kurz is the only exception here, since it was explicitly designed to use 8mm Mauser tooling for barrels, bullets and the base of the casing.
>Also is 5.7 to 5.56 what .300 blackout is to .308, 8mm kurz to 8mm mauser etc
No, because 5.7 is very definitely a pistol caliber, .300 Blackout and 8mm Kurz are not. Not get out of here with your Reddit spacing.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Previous >>55922136
Finally a new cover edition!

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

Is your best bet just mass fire at it and hope something hits? I wouldn't think this to be very effective, they're pretty small drones and can go pretty high up.

Watching all these videos of drones dropping grenades and mortar rounds really had me wondering on what someone in that situation could do. Even something like a 40mm grenade launcher with timed fuzes that would explode near it (would proximity fuses even work on something so small?) seems like a cheap solution? Is that even viable?

In any case it got me wondering. How would you try and deal with it assuming you're just some dudes innawoods and some other dudes are shitting grenades from the sky on you?

threads.com: I'm going to get an air pistol but am limited to 7.5 Joules. all the things I can see are in FPS though. how many fps are 7.5 joules? any recommendations on what to get? and on another note, what good are crossbows for hunting?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56068951
>how many fps are 7.5 joules?
Depends on how heavy the projectile is; Kinetic energy is 1/2 M x V squared. 7.5 joules is very weak though, it's going to be something roughly like an 8 grain pellet going 550 fps.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56068992
thanks that's helpful, so I could (in theory) get a gun with lots of fps and put a small pellet in it and have it be 7.5 J while at the same time having the ability to put bigger pellets in it but have more joule?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56069039
Put in a heavier pellet and you're going to get less fps, because the gun will only have so much energy stored up to give the pellet. The fps numbers you see listed are just whatever they got with whatever pellet they used to test it. Not that you'll always get the same muzzle velocity either, because how efficiently the gun transfers its stored energy into the pellet will also vary between pellets. And as for clever plans to skirt legality, if you think the authorities may end up checking then you may not want to rely on special pellets for staying legal, because the cops may not be kind enough to let you choose which pellet exactly they'll test with.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Shot a wounded pig once on a farm, only had lead round nose target loads at the time. Round went in the fuckers eye and did NOT kill it.

Shot placement and ammo selection matter. I've finished off plenty of animals with 9mm hollow points succsessfully.

>>56052219
If you're executing pigs for meat consumption and can damn near press the barrel to their skull? Yeah 100% every time. If you're innawood and get charged by a bunch of hogs and have to make quick shots on the way to the nearest tree to not die? I'd rather have something like 10mm or better. Everyone talking about "herp derp u can kill a cow wit a .22" is being a bit of an asshole - you can kill a cow standing still in a chute with a .22 to the forehead, you will absolutely not kill a cow from more than 10-20 yards away with a .22 from anything but blood loss over a pretty long period of time.
